insights.title: Price per unit exploded vs historical average
insights.observation: Current period average price per unit is $472,500, which is 16,600% higher than the buyer's historical average of $2,822.
insights.recommendation: Conduct a deep dive on the pricing of the Boiler Water Chemicals line—validate unit definitions, negotiate better terms, and explore alternative suppliers or products to bring unit cost closer to historical levels.

insights.title: Quantity purchased collapsed in the last 90 days
insights.observation: Only 2 units were bought in the current period versus 692 units over the buyer’s lifetime, a 99.7% drop.
insights.recommendation: Review demand forecasts and inventory policies to ensure the low purchase volume isn’t masking stock‑outs or hidden costs; consider consolidating orders if appropriate.

insights.title: Supplier base is thin compared to peers
insights.observation: The buyer used 1 supplier this period, while the industry average is 3.7 suppliers (below the 25th percentile).
insights.recommendation: Identify and qualify at least two additional qualified suppliers to reduce concentration risk and improve bargaining power.

insights.title: Unit cost far exceeds industry norm
insights.observation: Average price per unit ($472,500) is roughly 136× higher than the industry average unit price of about $3,452.
insights.recommendation: Benchmark the product’s cost structure against market rates, negotiate bulk discounts, or consider substitute chemicals with comparable performance at lower cost.

insights.title: Spend concentration spikes in a single period
insights.observation: The current 90‑day spend ($945k) accounts for 48% of the buyer’s total lifetime spend ($1.953M) while still being only 1.4% of the platform’s average period spend.
insights.recommendation: Implement spend smoothing tactics—budget larger purchases over multiple periods and monitor cash‑flow impact—to avoid reliance on single large transactions.

insights.title: Shift toward water‑treatment category
insights.observation: All current period spend is on the "Water treatment and supply equipment" category, whereas historically the top spend was on "Building construction machinery and accessories" ($1.008M).
insights.recommendation: Assess whether this category shift aligns with strategic objectives; if not, re‑evaluate procurement plans and explore cross‑category savings opportunities.
